Facility_id: 016
Specimen_type: Fresh Tissue
Pathology ReportSupplementary report 9/4/2067 further tissue, with ammended lymph node status

29R30720 (29R307203C) LESE, KOORI MARCEL  HISTOPATHOLOGY REPORT:

HISTORY:
Appendiceal cancer.  Liver.  Diaphragm strip.  Spleen. Omentum. Rectum/pelvis. Ileocolon.

MACROSCOPIC:
&quot;GALLBLADDER, OMENTUM, DIAPHRAGM, SPLEEN, RIGHT COLON, RECTOSIGMOID, LEFT LIVER, PERITONEAL DISEASE&quot;.  Received multiple tissue fragments in one jar, all appears involved with a disseminated white nodular surface deposits.
- The largest fragment is an en bloc specimen contains right and left colon adherent to each other by omental cake diffusely infiltrated by firm white deposit and peritoneal strips with multiple (up to 20 white deposits) measuring 5x15mm.  The right colon specimen contains a terminal ileum 90x35mm, caecum and ascending colon 125x110mm.  The rectosigmoid specimen measures 230x60mm with distal 40mm is below the anterior peritoneal reflection. No appendix is identified. The previously white deposit is also present at the anterior peritoneal reflection and the rectosigmoid area over 55x20mm.  The mucosal surfaces are unremarkable.  No polyps or tumours are identified.  No definite appendix is seen.  Attached to the peritoneum is a piece of skin (consistent with umbilicus) measuring 65x15mm.  The cut surface of the umbilicus reveals firm white tissue (? lesion) infiltrating the underlying fat to reach the attached peritoneum.  (1 right hemicolectomy proximal and distal margins; 2 rectosigmoid proximal margin; 3 rectosigmoid distal margin; 4&amp;5 umbilicus involvement; 6 terminal ileum; 7 caecum; 8&amp;9 continuous slices dense involvement of ileum mesentery; 10 four lymph node right colon; 11 sigmoid involvement; 12 rectal involvement; 13&amp;14 omentum cake with 14 tissue block for tumour banking; 15 peritoneal strip involvement)
- A length of small bowel measuring 110x35mm with attached mesocolon up to 25mm.  A nodule is identified on the serosal surface measuring 15mm and involves the adjacent mesocolon.  No mucosal polyps or tumours are identified.  (16 RS serosal involvement)
- A segment of liver of a total weight of 166g measuring 145x65x55mm. The surgical resection margin is inked blue.  The specimen is serially sliced. The liver parenchyma is homogenous, brown.  At the resection there is a white firm nodule measuring 35x15x15mm, appears surrounding a possible tubular structure (? ligament/? vessel) and is abutting the resection margin macroscopically. (17 normal liver; 18&amp;19 RS nodule)
- A spleen total weight of 158g measuring 110x90x45 mm. Firm white deposits are identified on the outer surface, largest measures 10mm at the hilum.  Attached is a piece of fibrofatty tissue consistent with omentum measuring 255x110x10 mm and has disseminated involvement (up to 80%) with firm white nodules 3-5mm in maximum diameter.
(20&amp;21 capsular involvement; 22 hilar involvement; 23 omental nodule)
- gallbladder 95x35x30 mm.  The outer surface is involved at the neck area by firm white deposits measuring 10mm and 15mm.  They appear clear of the cystic duct resection margin by 35mm. The wall is up to 4mm thick, becomes thickened at the area of nodular involvement up to 8mm.  The mucosal surface is green and granular.  Seven calculi are identified 5-10mm in maximum diameter. (24 cystic duct and TS neck [involved]; 25 TS body [involved and LS fundus)
- A firm white fibrous piece of tissue with attached muscle consistent with diaphragm measuring 155x135x15 mm about 70% is involved and thickened by firm white deposits.
(26&amp;27 diaphragmatic involvement). RS (M-27/ZH/ank)

MICROSCOPIC:
The tissue in the caecum/terminal ileum and adjacent mesentery is markedly distorted with involvement of mesentery by carcinoma. However no appendix is seen.
Sections of the peritoneal tumour deposits show:
- metastatic moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma without signet ring cells, which could also be classified as:
- high grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei/PMCA (peritoneal mucinous carcinomatosis) if from appendix.
The tumour is predominantly mucinous but has some non-mucinous adenocarcinoma areas and has variable patterns, but in nearly all areas the mucin is at least moderately cellular with plentiful epithelium arranged in strips, clusters, cribriform groups and single cells. There is definite invasion present in most areas of the tumour with the deepest level of invasion into muscularis propria of rectum approximately 3 mm, with deep invasion into mesenteric fat and omentum &gt;  10 mm, and invasion into subumbilical subcutaneous tissue.
There is tumour involvement of subumbilical tissue, terminal ileum, caecum, ileum mesentery, attached rectum, omentum, peritoneum, the separate piece of small bowel, liver hilum, surface of gallbladder, surface of spleen, and there is involvement of skeletal muscle, probably diaphragm tissue.
See previous report for mismatch repair protein.
Four lymph nodes were recovered from the specimen, these are free of tumour.
There is focal lymphovascular invasion (block 12).
Comment:
The appearances would be consistent with appendix origin in the proper clinical setting but other organ of origin is possible.
The appendix has not been idenitified ?previously removed.
The tumour appearances are similar to the previous biopsy specimen reviewed from 28/2/2066 (CHS Inc report 29R30720).
DIAGNOSIS:
RESECTION OF MULTIPLE INTRA-ABDOMINAL/PERITONEAL TISSUES:
- metastatic moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma without signet ring cells(if of uncertain organ origin)
or:
- high grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei/PMCA (peritoneal mucinous carcinomatosis), if of appendix origin.
- lymphovascular invasion present
Further sections pending
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
Supplementary report 9/4/2067 further tissue:
Further tissue: (31 ?collection at the base of the caecum; 32-35 lymph nodes around the ileocaecal valve region [32 five lymph nodes; 33 one lymph node, trisected, ?involved; 34 one lymph node bisected; 35 five lymph nodes). RS (M-35/ZH/cy)

In the further examined lymph nodes from ileocaecal region, one lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma.

LYMPH NODES:
Site: Ileocaecal region
Positive (involved)
Lymph nodes examined: 	13
Positive lymph nodes: 	1
Largest metastatic deposit: 	13 mm diameter
Other lymph nodes (L colon mesentery lymph nodes x 2) are not involved. There are extranodal tumour deposits in left colon mesentery and numerous extranodal deposits in ileocaecal mesentery.
Other findings:
A section of ureter is present in the left colon sections.
Provisional stage: pT0 (primary tumour not identified) pN1 pM1a

Staging by TNM 7th ed 2010

ANNENDED DIAGNOSIS: (after further lymph node examination):

RESECTION OF MULTIPLE INTRA-ABDOMINAL/PERITONEAL TISSUES:
- metastatic moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma without signet ring cells (if of uncertain organ origin), (intraperitoneal metastases)
or:
- high grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei/PMCA (peritoneal mucinous carcinomatosis), if of appendix origin (intraperitoneal metastases)
- lymphovascular invasion present
- lymph node metastasis present (1/13 ileocolic nodes positive)

SOLON, Merrill 
Lab No:  90E53839
Kruhm
LAUNCHING PLACE  TAS  3556
Specimen: Tissue

Sex:  F
Collected: 11/8/2064 at :
Location:  ONCOLOGY (GYNAE)-GRIFFITH BASE HOSPITAL
DR BOYCE Mike SUMP
Distribution:    NSW-CANCER-REGISTRY
CLINICAL:
1.  Right hemihepatectomy.  2.  Peritoneal nodule.  Previous (R) nephrectomy & liver resection for atypical renal cell carcinoma.   Freezing of tumour for genotyping & molecular mapping.  
Additional:
Frozen tumour to be held at PETERBOROUGH CAMPUSfor potential genotype/ molecular mapping at Jones Apparel Group as per Prof Y Hillian (ND).

MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Right liver" consists of a portion of liver 140 x 70 x 70mm with a large circumscribed tumour 60 x 60 x 60mm.  As the tumour was openedprior to fixation the capsular surface appears disrupted however on further sectioning the tumour appears to abut the capsule surface but not penetrate through it.  There are some small amounts of fibrinous material overlying this area.  The tumour appears to come within 4mm of the surgical resection margin.  The remainder of the liver appears unremarkable.  Tumour and non tumour frozen and biobanked(by ZO 1200 06.09.14)
Blocks:  1 & 2 - tumour to surgical resection margin; 3 to 6 - further tumour to capsular surface; 7 - ?tumour on capsule; 8- uninvolved liver; 9 - reserved block/
B.  Specimen labelled "Peritoneal nodule" consists of a piece of fatty tissue measuring 45 x 35 x 15mm.  A well circumscribed nodule is identified measuring 20mm in maximum dimension.  Nodule is serially sectioned AE 2 blocks. Tumour and non tumour frozen and biobanked (by LY 1200 06.09.14)
(TO: FT:  CO/mm 11.10.64) 
MICROSCOPIC:  (Reportedby Dr Y Jergen & Dr Y Fouquet)
A.  Section of the livershow a 60mm deposit of metastatic carcinoma. The carcinoma is relatively well circumscribed with a thin fibrous pseudocapsule at the advancing edge. The tumour has a mixed papillary, alveolar and nested architecture with large areas of haemorrhage. The cells are large and polygonal with abundant clear to granular eosinophilic cytoplasm with patchy intracytoplasmic Schmorls positive melanin. The nuclei are central to eccentrically located with coarse to vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli.  There are also occasional cells with large pleomorphic nuclei and/or multiple nuclei, prominent macronucleoli, consistent with Fuhrmann and ISUP grade 4. In some areas there are vaguely nodular areas of smaller cells surrounded by areas of larger more pleomorphic cells.  Rare foci of psammomatous calcifications are seen.  Mitosis are inconspicuous (less than 1/10 hpf) and there are patchy small foci of necrosis comprising than 5% of the tumour.  There are patchy foci of intratumoural acute and subacute haemorrhage. 
In areas the tumour abuts the liver capsule or is separated from it by intervening compressed hepatic parenchyma.  There is associated overlying capsular organising haemorrhage, however, no capsular penetration is seen.  The surgical resection margin is 5mm clear.  Thereare two foci highly suspicious for lymphovascular invasion adjacent to the subcapsular edge of the tumour (A3).  
The current subcapsular hepatic deposit shows similar features to the previously excised deposit on the capsular surface of the liver (90E53839) and paracaval lymph nodes metastases (90E53839) and is consistent with metastatic Xp11 translocation carcinoma (original renal primary diagnosis by Dr Y Drott and Dr Y Jelsma in nephrectomy specimen (YAE53839-31DX). 
Adjacent to the tumour there are scatted foci of granulomatous inflammation  including foci containing polarisable suture material consistent with previous surgery.  No pathogenic organisms are seen on dPAS or Fite stains. 
The uninvolved liver displays a preserved lobular architecture. There are occasional degenerate neutrophils and lymphocytes within the portal tracts most likely due to surgery. There is no significant interface hepatitis, lobular inflammation, steatosis or fibrosis. No iron deposition or intrahepatic bile seen on Perls or Halls staining.
B.  Sections show fibroadipose tissue containing a 20mm deposit of metastatic carcinoma with similar features to the liver tumour, consistent with metastatic Xp11 translocation renal carcinoma. No lymphovascular invasion is seen.

DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Right liver:
-    60mm subcapsular deposit consistent with metastatic Xp11 translocation renal carcinoma, margin clear.
B.  Peritoneal nodule:
 -   Consistent with metastatic Xp11 translocation renal carcinoma.

CLINICAL:

MACROSCOPIC:

Blocks: 1 & 2 - lymph node from imprint cytology; 3 - further lymph node identified. 
FROZEN SECTIONREPORT:

B.  Specimen labelled "Left breast short superior, long lateral" consists of a mastectomy measuring 250mm (medial to lateral) x 190mm (inferior to superior) x 50mm (superficial to deep).  There is an overlying ellipse of skin measuring 195mm (medial to lateral) x 75mm (inferior to superior).  This includes a nipple areola complex measuring 35 x 35mm which appears unremarkable.  The superficial margin is inked blue and the deep margin inked black.  The cut surface reveals two tumour.  Tumour one is identified in the 12 o'clock position 75mm from the nipple and measures 23mm (medial to lateral) x 24mm (inferior to superior) x 20mm (superficial to deep).  Tumour one is 23mm from the superior superficial margin and 18mm from the deep margin, and the medial, lateral and inferior margins are well clear.  Tumour two is identified in the 2 o'clock position 110mm from the nipple and measures 10mm (medial to lateral) x 11mm (inferior to superior) x 8mm (superficial to deep).  The deep margin is 20mm from the tumour and the inferior superficial margin is 45mm away while the medial lateral and superior margins are well clear.  Two ?lymph nodes are identified in the axillary tail.  Nofurther suspicious lesions are identified.  
Blocks: 1 to 4 - tumour one; 5 & 6 - tumour two; 7 - inferior margin and near tumourtwo; 8 & 9 - representative inner upper quadrant; 10 & 11 - representative inner lower quadrant; 12 & 13 - representative outer lower quadrant; 14 & 15 - representative outer upper quadrant; 16 - nipple and tissue deep from the nipple; 17 - lymph nodes; 18 - reserve block.
 
C.  Specimen labelled "Axillary node dissection level one left breast" consists of a piece of fatty tissue measuring 90 x 80 x 25mm in aggregate.  Multiple lymph nodes are identified from 2 to 30mm.  
Blocks: 1 to 3 - lymph nodes;4 & 5 - one lymph node bisected.

:
A.  Specimen labelled "Uterus, cervix, bilateral tube + ovaries" consists of a uterus with attached cervix, bilateralfallopian tubes and ovaries weighing 158g in total.  The uterus measures 95 x 70 x 50mm and has a smooth shiny serosal surface.  The ectocervix measures 30 x 25mm and has an unremarkable surface.  On sectioning the endometrium is 1mm in maximum thickness and the myometrium is 25mm in maximum thickness.  The myometrium is unremarkable.  The right fallopian tube measures 75mm in length and 9mm in maximum diameter.  Theright ovary measures 38 x 25 x 20mm and contains unilocular cyst 10mm in maximum dimension filled with clear fluid.  The left fallopian tube measures 55mm in length and up to 8mm in maximum diameter.  The left ovary measures 35 x 30 x 20mm and contains a unilocular cyst filled with clear fluid, 18mmin maximum dimension.  Ovaries and fallopian tubes have been blocked entirely.  
Blocks: 1 to 5 - full LS of anterior body and cervix; 6 to 10 - full LS ofposterior body and cervix; 11 to 17 - right ovary; 18 to 21 - right fallopian tube; 22 to 26 - left ovary; 27 to 29 - left fallopian tube.
  
B.  Specimen labelled "Omentum" consists of a piece of omental fatty tissue 50 x 45 x 15mm.  Slicing reveals a yellow glistening cut surface.  No nodules are identified.  
Blocks: 1 to 3 - random sections.   (AQ/ta 23/10/63)

A.  The ectocervix and endocervix show no significant abnormality.  The endometrium is proliferative.  The myometrium is unremarkable.  The ovaries and tubes have been examined in their entirety.  The ovaries show a few follicular cysts.  The tubes are unremarkable.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
B.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Uterus, ovaries and tubes:  No significant abnormality detected.
B.  Omentum:   No significant abnormality detected.

Pathology ReportCLINICAL:
66 year old female.  Grade 2 endometrial cancer.
Additional:  No obvious tumour seen macroscopically - no research sample taken (NL).


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Uterus, tubes, ovaries&quot;, consists of a uterus with attached cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes, and ovaries, 41g in total.  The uterus measures 80 x 45 x 30mm and has a smooth shiny serosal surface.  The ectocervix measures 28 x 28mm and has an unremarkable surface.  The anterior cervical margin is inked green and the posterior cervical margin is inked black.  On sectioning, the endometrium measures 3mm in maximum thickness.   The thickened area includes tumour measuring roughly 18 x 9mm in area.  The tumour appears to extend to maximum depth of 4mm.  The myometrium measures 16mm in maximum thickness.  The left ovary, 14 x 12 x 5mm, has an unremarkable cut surface.  The left fallopian tube, 42 x 3 x 3mm, is unremarkable.  The right ovary, 15 x 12 x 8mm has an unremarkable cut surface. The right fallopian tube, 40 x 4 x 3mm, is unremarkable.
Blocks: 1 and 2 - composite mid line LS anterior uterus and cervix; 3 and 4- LS anterior uterus; 5 and 6 - composite midline LS posterior uterus and cervix; 7 to 9 - LS posterior uterus; 10 - complete left ovary; 11 - LS complete fimbrial end left fallopian tube, and mid TS; 12 - complete right ovary; 13 - LS complete fimbrial end right fallopian tube, and mid TS; Reselect blocks - 14-16 LS remaining anterior endometrium; 17 &amp; 18 - LS remaining posterior endometrium. All endometrium embedded.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of omental tissue, 45 x 30 x 20mm.  On thin sectioning, no masses or lymph nodes are identified.  RS in 3 blocks.  (TO: JB;JB/vo 24.10.66)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr R Ochsenbein):
A. Sections show endometrioid adenocarcinoma, grade 2, confined to the endometrium. The lesion is composed of complex back-to-back glands. In some areas, there are tumour cells with enlarged, pleomorphic, vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli, consistent with severe (grade 3) nuclear atypia. Focal squamous morule formation is present. No significant solid component is seen, consistent with an overall grade of 2. No lymphovascular invasion is identified.

The uninvolved endometrium is inactive.
The cervix shows no evidence of HPV effect or CIN.
The fallopian tubes and ovaries are unremarkable.
Mismatch Repair Deficiency (MMRD) Status
MLH1		Preserved nuclear staining
PMS2		Preserved nuclear staining
MSH2		Preserved nuclear staining
MSH6		Preserved nuclear staining

Comment:
Preserved nuclear staining of a carcinoma for MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

B. Sections show omental fat with no evidence of malignancy.
DIAGNOSIS
A. Uterus and cervix, fallopian tubes and ovaries: endometrioid adenocarcinoma, grade 2, confined to the endometrium
B. Omentum: no evidence of malignancy

CLINICAL:
51yr old,risk reducing surgery as BRCA 2 carrier.  TAH BSO.  Please section whole tube and ovary on each side as per BRCA protocol.  
MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled "Uterus, tubes and ovaries" consists of a uterus with attached cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries which was received fixed in formalin and weighed 91g in total. (1 spleen; 2&3 small bowel ends; 4 tumour attached to gallbladder; 5 gallbladder tumour; 6 gallbladder body; 7 peritoneal nodules; 8&9 omental nodules; 10 tumour at anastomosis site; 11 lesion at proximal end of sigmoid; 12nodule just above distal resection margin of rectum; 13 nodule just below anterior peritoneal reflection [numerous staples includes]; 14 proximal resection margin sigmoid;15 distal resection margin rectum). Sections show widespread metastatic moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows extensive involvement of the omentum and strips of peritoneum,the serosal surface of the gallbladder, together with mesocolic and perirectal fatty deposits. The carcinoma is characterised by lakes of mucin lined by malignant epithelium with moderate to marked cytologic atypia, together with infiltrating malignant glands within desmoplastic stroma. 
The tumour described in the segment of colon including the probable anastomotic site, (anastomosis not confirmed in the sections), is the likely primary site. There is an in-situ villous component with high grade dysplasia merging with invasive malignancy extending into pericolic fat. The tumour described at the proximal end of the sigmoid colon shows features favouring metastatic origin. The bulk of the tumour is within the muscularis propria and fat, but does extend to ulcerate the mucosa which is otherwise non dysplastic. 
Sections of the splenic parenchyma are unremarkable. Sections of small bowel mucosa are unremarkable. Thegallbladder mucosa is largely autolyzed in the sections examined.

SEGMENTS OF COLON AND RECTUM, SMALLBOWEL, SPLEEN, GALLBLADDER, OMENTUM AND PERITONEUM -

- METASTATIC DEPOSITS WITHIN SIGMOID COLON AND PERIRECTAL TISSUES, PERITONEUM, OMENTUM AND SURFACE OF THE GALLBLADDER.

There are frequent mitoses.  The tumour cells are positive for CD10, CD20, CD45, CD79a, Bcl-6, p53 and Bcl-2.  CD3 and CD5 highlight scattered reactive T cells in the background.  The stains for Cyclin D1, MNF-116, ER, PAX8, CK7, CK20, WT-1, S100, Vimentin, SMA and Desmin are negative.  The Ki-67 proliferation index is more than 70%.  The appearances are those of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.  There is no evidence of serous carcinoma.


DIAGNOSIS:
A to D.  Omentum, adnexal mass and left pelvic side wall - Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT:

CLINICAL:
79yo F. Ovarian Ca. Debulking OT. Additional history: previous core favoured High grade serous carcinoma, had adjuvant therapy


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left fallopian tube + ovary&quot;, consists of a fallopian tube and a solid cystic ovarian mass, 55 x 45 x 30mm. The mass is adherent to the fallopian tube and has a smooth outer surface with some roughened areas. The cut surface shows a uniloculated cyst with papillary and solid areas. The solid area makes up approximately 20% of the mass. Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - fallopian tube with adherent ovarian mass; 3 to 10 - RS ovarian mass; 11 - biobank. RS. Shown to Dr C Niro.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right tube + ovary&quot;, consists of a fallopian tube and ovary with attached ligament, 50 x 40 x 20mm. The fallopian tube is 60mm in length and up to 8mm in maximum diameter. There is a solid cystic mass, 10 x 7 x 6mm attached to the fallopian tube. The ovary measures 20 x 12 x 10mm. There is also another solid cystic lesion, 8 x 10 x 5mm attached to the ovary. The ovary has an unremarkable cut surface. Shown to Dr C Lozaya. Blocks: 1 to 8 - fallopian tube and ovary. RS.

C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right round ligament&quot;, consists of a tan to haemorrhagic nodular piece of tissue, 20 x 15 x 8mm. Sectioned and AE 2 blocks.

D.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right uterosacral&quot;, consists of a fragment of ligament and attached solid cystic mass, 40 x 20 x 18mm. The attached solid cystic mass is 25 x 20 x 15mm. Serially sectioned and AE 6 blocks.

E.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right rectal mass&quot;, consists of multiple fragments of friable, tan and fatty tissue, 90 x 65 x 30mm in aggregate. Shown to Dr C Ostlie. Unable to identify rectum in specimen. There are areas of haemorrhage but no obvious necrosis seen. Blocks: 1 to 4 - one almost complete face of tumour; 5 to 9 - further RS mass. RS.

F.  Specimen labelled &quot;Rectal tumour&quot;, consists of an irregular tan and haemorrhagic piece of tissue with attached adipose tissue, 60 x 20 x 18mm. Cut surface shows solid and papillary areas. Serially sectioned and AE 6 blocks.

G.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left rectal nodule&quot;, consists of a multinodular tan tissue with attached adipose tissue, 32 x 20 x 10mm. The cut surface is pale, firm and nodular. Serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.

H.  Specimen labelled &quot;Rectal mesentery&quot;, consists of an irregular tan and haemorrhagic piece of tissue, with attached adipose tissue, 30 x 20 x 13mm. Serially sliced and AE 2 blocks.

I.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid nodule&quot;, consists of a tan and haemorrhagic nodule with attached adipose tissue, 33 x 25 x 20mm. The nodule has a rough outer surface, and the cut surface shows a pale and uniform cut surface. Serially sectioned and AE 5 blocks. RS.

J.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid mesentery&quot;, consists of tan and haemorrhagic fibrofatty tissue, 23 x 15 x 8mm. Sectioned and AE 1 block.

K.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid epiploic&quot;, consists of a piece of fatty tissue with attache tan nodule, 33 x 20 x 10mm. There are multiple pale to tan nodules attached ranging from 3 to 10mm in maximum diameter. Serially sectioned AE 2 blocks.

L.  Specimen labelled &quot;Bladder nodule&quot;, consists of a fibrous piece of tissue with attached multinodular mass, 35 x 18 x 13mm. There is a multicystic mass measuring 10 x 6 x 7mm attached. Resection margin inked. Serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.

M.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right common iliac lymph node&quot;, consists of haemorrhagic and fatty piece of tissue, 35 x 20 x 15mm. On sectioning, there does not appear to be a normal lymph node and appears to be a solid cystic nodule with about 50% of the nodule being solid and the solid areas also contain papillary areas as well. Shown to Dr C Menietto. Serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.

N.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of a piece of fatty tissue with attached multiple solid cystic masses 340 x 340 x 45mm in total. There are up to nine solid cystic masses ranging from 25mm to 85mm in maximum diameter. The cut surface of the larger mass appears to be cystic and solid areas with necrosis. Shown to Dr C Connealy. Blocks: 1 to 10 - RS solid cystic mass. RS.
(TO:DN/ta 3/5/71)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr C Deible):
A. The left fallopian tube and ovary are widely replaced by High grade Serous carcinoma showing no convincing response to adjuvant therapy.

It is characterised by widely cystic papillary appearance with areas of more solid and micropapillary appearance and in other areas the tumour tracks through stroma associated with a desmoplastic reaction. Scattered calcifications are seen. The tumour shows variable pleomorphism including marked atypical cells and nucleoli. The fimbrial end is lined partially by tumour cells resembling the carcinoma in keeping with fallopian tube origin.

The ovary shows a corpus albicans.

Immunohistochemistry:
Pax8: diffusely positive
P53: patchy positive
WT1: widespread strong positive
CA125: widespread positive
ER: widespread positive
PR: negative
CK7: widespread positive
CK20: negative

B. The right ovary is involved by the carcinoma. Some mesothelial inclusion cysts and corpora albicantes are noted. The fallopian tube shows no in situ component.

C. The right round ligament is widely involved by carcinoma.

D. The right uterosacral fibrous tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.

E. The right rectal tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.

F. The rectal fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma. A focus is suspicious for lymphovascular invasion. An unremarkable lymph node is included (0/1).

G. The left rectal fibrofatty tissue is widely involved by carcinoma. Lymphovascular invasion is present.

H. The rectal mesentery fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.

I. The sigmoid fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma and extends into one lymph node (1/1).

J. The sigmoid mesentery fibrofatty tissue is widely involved by carcinoma.

K. The sigmoid epiploic fibrofatty tissue is involved by carcinoma.

L. The bladder nodule shows fibrofatty tissue and some columnar mucosa and is involved by carcinoma.

M. The right common iliac lymph node is widely replaced by carcinoma (1/1). The deposit is at least 14mm across and no convincing extranodal extension is seen.

N. The omental fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.

DIAGNOSIS:
A. Left fallopian tube + ovary: High grade Serous carcinoma.

B. Right tube + ovary: High grade Serous carcinoma.

C. Right round ligament: High grade Serous carcinoma.

D. Right uterosacral: High grade Serous carcinoma.

E. Right rectal mass: High grade Serous carcinoma.

F. Rectal tumour: High grade Serous carcinoma.

G. Left rectal nodule: High grade Serous carcinoma.

H. Rectal mesentery: High grade Serous carcinoma.

I. Sigmoid nodule: High grade Serous carcinoma including one involved lymph node.

J. Sigmoid mesentery: High grade Serous carcinoma.

K. Sigmoid epiploic: High grade Serous carcinoma.

L. Bladder nodule: High grade Serous carcinoma.

M. Right common iliac lymph node: High grade Serous carcinoma in one lymph node.

N. Omentum: High grade Serous carcinoma.


SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (6/7/2071):
P53 staining is variable in the tumour with some areas showing 80% strong expression and some areas show occasional mild and some wider areas no expression of p53. The features would be in keeping with mutation type p53 expression.

MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Uterus, cervix, bilateral tubes and ovaries", consists of total hysterectomy with attached tubes and ovaries the uterus measures 95 x 50 x 20mm andweighs 70g. and has a smooth and shiny serosal surface, the cervix measures 20 x 20mm and has an unremarkable surface.  The endometrial cavity it totally filled an exophytic friable tumour.  The endometrium has a maximum thickness of 10mm and the myometrium at the level of the tumour has a maximum thickness of 3mm.  The right fallopian tube and fimbrial measure 50mm in length and 5mm in maximum diameter and appears unremarkable.  The right ovary measures 30 x 15 x 15mmon sectioning there is a cyst filled with yellow creamy material, the cyst measures 20mm in maximum diameter.  The right fallopian tube and fimbrial measure 55mm in length and 5mm in maximum diameter.  The left ovary measures 30 x 15 x 15mm and appears unremarkable.  
Blocks: 1 to 4 - one full longitudinal section of anterior body and cervix; 5and 6 - two representative sections of anterior endomyometrium; 7 to 11 - one full longitudinal section of posterior body and cervix; 11 and 12- two representative sections of posterior endomyometrium; 13 - right cornu; 14 - left cornu; 15 - right parametrial tissue; 16 - left parametrial tissue; 17 - 2LS right fimbria and 1TS right fallopian tube; 18 - 2LS left fimbria and 1TS left fallopian tube; 19 to 21 ovary with cystic lesion; 22 - left ovary; AE.
B.  Specimen labelled "Right obturator lymph node", consists of a large fatty lymph node measuring 40 x 10 x 10mm AE 3 blocks. 
C.  Specimen labelled "Left external iliac lymph node", consists of a piece of fatty tissue containing two lymph nodes 5 and 15mm in maximum diameter.
Blocks: 1 - one lymph node; 2 - one bisected lymph node; 3 - rest of fatty tissue.
D.  Specimen labelled "Left obturator lymph node", consists of four lymph nodes measuring from 10 to 35mm in maximum diameter.
Blocks: 1 - two lymph nodes; 2 - one bisected lymph node; 3 - one bisected lymph node.

Blocks: 1 - three lymph nodes; 2 - two lymph nodes; 3 - rest of fatty tissue.
(TO: TZ;GQ/vo 12.9.63)

MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr F Loftin):
A. Sections show a grade 2 endometrioid adenocarcinoma involving the anterior and posterior uterine walls. 80% of the lesion has a complex glandular architecture and 20% of the lesion has a solid architecture. There is no convincing severe nuclear atypia, in keeping with agrade of 2.
At the deepest point of invasion in the anterior wall, the lesion has invaded 6 mm into a wall 10mm thick.
There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or invasion into the cervix.
Theovaries and fallopian tubes show no evidence of malignancy.
A 20mm mature cystic teratoma composed of a cyst lined by squamous epithelium and adipose tissue is present in the right ovary.
Adenomyosis is seen in themyometrium.
There is no evidence of CIN or HPV effect in the cervix.
Shown to Dr Dewey GEDE.
Mismatch Repair Deficiency (MMRD) Status	
MLH1		Preserved nuclear staining
PMS2		Preserved nuclear staining
MSH2		Preserved nuclear staining
MSH6		Loss of nuclear staining (repeated twice, satisfactory staining seen in 		internal and external positive controls)
Comment:
Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair gene.
B. Sections show 1 lymph node with no evidence of malignancy.
C. Sections show 2 lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy.
D. Sections show 4 lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy.
E. Sections show 5 lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy.
DIAGNOSIS
A. Uterus, cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries:
- Grade 2 endometrioid adenocarcinoma, invading the outer half of the uterine wall (6mm into a wall 10mm thick), no lymphovascular invasion identified
- Cervix, ovaries and fallopian tubes with no evidence of malignancy
- Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) right ovary
B to E. Right obturator, left external iliac, left obturator and right external lymph nodes: 12lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy

SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (13.9.64):


CLINICAL:
Left temporal lobe intra-axial lesion.  ?GBM/high grade glioma.
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Left temporal lesion" consists of two pieces of tissue 8 x 8 x 3mm and 10 x 4 x 4mm.  Half for frozen section and smear.
Blocks:1- frozen section; 2- rest of frozen section.
FROZEN SECTION REPORT:
High grade glial tumour.
Phone result to anaesthetist by Dr Z Windsor at 16.15pm on 04.06.14.
B.  Specimen labelled "Left temporal lobe intra-axial lesion" consists of a piece of brain measuring 30 x 20 x 20mm.  Macroscopically white matter and grey matter are identified.  The surgical margin of the tumour is friable.  AE 8 blocks.
(UU/mm 8.7.64) 
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr Z Budds):
A.  Sections show pieces of tumour tissue.  The tumour is cellular and consists of cells with medium sized and large, pleomorphic nuclei and generally scant eosinophilic cytoplasmwith poorly defined cell borders.  The nuclei tend to be oval or spindle shaped and the cells lie within a fibrillary background.  Mitoses are frequent, numbering up to 10/10 HPF.  There is microvascular proliferation and also palisaded tumour necrosis.  The features are of a glioblastoma (WHO grade 4).
Immunohistochemical stains:
GFAP:  Positive.
IDH1:  Negative.
p53:  Patchy positive staining.
Ki-67:  Moderate proliferation index, up to around 20%.
Molecular tests:  Tissue will be forwarded to the Lowy Centre for MGMT testing and a supplementary report issued.
Block for potential treatment trial (if required):
Viable tumour (with less procedural artefact) is best seen in block A2.
B.  Sections show brain tissue including grey mater and white mater.  Much of the tissue is essentially normal but there is partial involvement of the tissue by high grade glioma with a similar appearanceto specimen A.  There is microvascular proliferation and also tumour necrosis.
DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Left temporal tumour:  Glioblastoma (WHO grade 4).
B.  Left temporal lobe:  Glioblastoma.  

SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (13.9.64):
MGMT testing was performed at the TRUNDLE MULTI PURPOSE SERVICE Research Centre.
DNA was extracted, bisulphite modified and subjected to pyrosequencing to amplify a region of the MGMT promoter in order to detect methylation.
The sample was tested twice with the appropriate controls and was found to be unmethylated (10%) at the MGMT promoter region.
Reported by Dr Z Baiza.
Please note that this test was performed in a research laboratory which is not NATA accredited.

SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (4.7.64):


CLINICAL:
Pelvic mass.  Son bowel cancer age 55.  Osteoarthritis.Likely ovarian cancer.
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "R ovary" consists of a solid and cystic ovarian mass measuring 110 x 90 x 60mm and weighing 335g.  There is some attached fat ?omentum measuring 100 x 30 x 10mm.  The outer surface of the mass is smooth.  The tube is not identified.  On sectioning there is a variegated yellow to cream solid area 60mm in maximum dimension.  The rest of the mass is cystic.  Representative in 13 blocks.
Blocks:  1 & 2- frozen section deblocked; 3 to 13 - ovarian mass.
FROZEN SECTION REPORT:
High grade carcinoma consistent with serous.
Result by Dr SA to Q Matsko on the 24th of March 2064.
B.  Specimen labelled "Left tube and ovary, uterus + cx" consists of a uterus with attached cervix and left fallopian tube and ovary weighing 98g in total.  The uterus measures 85 x 45 x 30mm and has a smooth shiny serosal surface.  The ectocervix measures 25 x 20mm and has an unremarkable surface.  On sectioning the endometrium is 3mm thick and the myometrium is up to 16mm in maximum thickness.  The myometrium is unremarkable.  The left fallopian tube measures 35mm in length x 7 x 7mm in maximum dimension.  The left ovary measures 30 x 10 x 10mm and has an unremarkable cut surface. 
Blocks:  1 to 3 - full LS of anterior body and cervix; 4 to 6 - full LS of posterior body and cervix; 7 to 8 - fallopian tube, AE; 9 & 10 - ovary, AE.
C.  Specimen labelled "Omentum" consists of fibrofatty tissue measuring 450 x 100 x 10mm.  No discrete masses or lymph nodes are identified within the specimen.  There is a haemorrhagic area which corresponds to a surgical suture.  Otherwise, the omentum is unremarkable.  Representative in 3 blocks.
Blocks:  1 - haemorrhagic area next to surgical suture, 2 - normal omentum.
D.  Specimen labelled "Appendix" consists of an appendix measuring 50mm in length x 7 x 6mm in maximum dimension.  The external surface is smooth and shiny.  The mesoappendix measures 30x 20 x 7mm.  The wall thickness is 2mm and the mucosa appears unremarkable.  AE in 3 blocks.
Blocks:  1 - TS proximal surgical margin; two LS proximal; 2 - three TS mid; 3 - two LS distal.
E.  Specimen labelled "Peritoneal cyst" consists of two cystic structures measuring 40 x 20 x 20mm and 13 x 10 x 5mm.  The outer surfaces are smooth lined and on sectioning the cysts are filled with green tinged serous fluid.  The walls are thin and there are no solid areas identified.  Both cysts are unilocular.  AE 3 blocks.
Blocks:  1 & 2 - larger cyst; 3 - smaller cyst.
F.  Specimen labelled "Omental nodule" consists of a piece of fibrofatty tissue measuring 20 x 20 x 6mm.  No mass lesions or lymph nodes are identified within the fatty tissue.  AE 1 block.
G.  Specimen labelled "Caecal nodules" consists of seven piecesof tan tissue from 1 to 3mm in maximum dimension.  AE 1 block.
H.  Specimen labelled "Descending colon nodule" consists of a polypoid tan nodule measuring 10 x 8 x 8mm.  The external surface is haemorrhagic but smooth and on sectioning there is a brown tan centre surrounded by solid areas with a variegated yellow to grey appearance.  BAE 1 block.  (TO: AP; GP/rt 25.3.64)
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr Q Marrone):
A.  Sections of right adnexal mass show a papilliform carcinoma with extensive necrosis.  The tumour has a complex cribriform and slender papillary architecture.  The tumour cells have elongated, round to oval nuclei with vesicular chromatin anda variable amount of cytoplasm.  The nuclei are pleomorphic, with irregular nuclear contours, coarse chromatin and nucleoli.  Some cells are multinucleate.  Mitoses are frequent.  Occasional psammoma bodies are identified.  The featuresare of a moderately differentiated serous carcinoma.  There is some rather florid reactive mesothelial proliferation within, and on the surface of, the mass but no tumour is identified on the serosal surface.
B.  The ectocervix and endocervix are unremarkable. The endometrium is atrophic. There is adenomyosis and there is a small leiomyoma in the myometrium.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
The left tube and ovary are unremarkable.
C.  Sections show fat.  There are small foci of chronic inflammation but no tumour is seen.
D.  Sections of appendix show a small carcinoid tumour at the tip.  It measures 9mm diameter in the sections.  It invades through the appendix wall into subserosal fat.  No tumour is seen on the serosal surface.  There is focal perineural invasion in the subserosa but no definite lymphovascular invasion is seen.  The tumour is around 18mm from the proximal appendiceal resection margin.  There is some reactive mesothelial proliferation on the serosal surface of the appendix.    
 E.  Sections show a cyst lined by simple flattened and cuboidal epithelium.  The wall of the cyst is thin, and there are multiple small calibre blood vessels within the cyst wall.  There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy.  
F.  Sections of omentum show mature adipose tissue. There are a few foci of mild fibrosis and reactive mesothelialproliferation but no tumour is seen.
G.  Sections of caecal nodules show adipose tissue with focal mild chronic inflammation and mesothelial reaction.  No tumour is seen.
H.  Sections show necrotic fat with infiltrating giant cells, chronic inflammatory cells and histiocytes at the periphery.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Right ovary:  Moderately differentiated serous carcinoma.
B.  Uterus, left tube and ovary:  No significant abnormality.
C.  Omentum:  No tumour.
D.  Appendix:  Carcinoid tumour.
E.  Peritoneal cyst:  Benign cyst.
F.  Omental nodule:  No tumour.
G.  Caecal nodules:  No tumour.
H.  Descending colon nodule:  Fat necrosis.  


SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (4.7.64):
A.  Immunostains for hormone receptors have been performed as requested.
Oestrogen receptor:   Positive.

			Predominant intensity of staining:  Strong.
Progesterone receptor:   Focal positive.
			0.5% of tumour cells show positive staining.
			Predominant intensity of staining:  Strong.

***SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT ADDED: EXTERNAL PATHOLOGY REVIEW 
(Professor Bement, 105 HAMRUN CIRCUIT Pathologists) 

CLINICAL:
Left hemi hepatectomy.  Left lobe of liver, gallbladder.  
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled "Left lateral liver" consists of a wedge of liver measuring 190 x 95 x 40mm and weighing 351g.  There are two exposed areas (presumed surgical margin) measuring 100 x 35mm and 60 x 15mm, both inked blue.  The staple margin is removed and inked black.  On sectioning there is an irregular cream mass (nodule 1) measuring 30 x 20 x 35mm that appears to abut the surgical margin.  There is a further triangular subcapsular lesion (nodule 2) measuring 30 x 20 x 40mm. Between nodule 1 and 2 there are several cream nodules 5-10mm. The liver also contains several dilated ducts, two calculi are present within these ducts, 10 and 12mm. The remaining liver parenchyma is macroscopically unremarkable.
Blocks: 1 & 2 - (paired blocks) mass deep to surgical margin; 3 to 5  - sections from base of nodule 1 to nodule 2 ; 6 - further section of mass nodule 1; 7 & 8 - (paired blocks) representative nodule 2; 9 - further section of nodule 2; 10 - section of macroscopically uninvolved liver.
B.  Specimen labelled "Gallbladder" consists of a gallbladder received unopened measuring 80 x 40 x 25mm.  The serosal surface appears congested.  Nocystic duct lymph node is identified.  One gallstone is contained within the gallbladder measuring 30 x 23 x 15mm.  The mucosa appears slightly flattened in areas but is otherwise unremarkable.  The maximum wall thickness is 3mm.
Blocks: 1 - cystic duct; 2 - two TS gallbladder body; 3 - two LS gallbladder fundus.  
(FJ/ta 26/7/63) 
MICROSCOPIC:  (Reported by Dr Q Rosebure)
A.  Sections of the liver lesion show broad area of confluent fibrosis containing variably ectatic to narrowed bile ducts and a moderate to heavy mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate. Some of the larger ducts contain small remnants of calculus debris attached to their reactive epithelial lining, while smaller ducts show periductal oedema and luminal narrowing. Some of the ducts contain acute inflammatory cells  with inflammatory cell exocytosis and patchy mild reactive change of the epithelium. A proliferation of small calibre bile ducts is present in areas. The inflammation consists of lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophils,histiocytes and neutrophils. There are scattered foreign body giant cells, some of which surround cholesterol cleft like spaces, as well as, a granuloma. No pathogenic organisms are seen with PASf and truants. No significant cytologicatypia or necrosis is identified. The lesion extends to within 0.25mm of the inked margin. The immediately adjacent liver parenchyma shows large duct obstructive type changes including a bile ductular proliferation and acute inflammation within the portal tracts. The uninvolved liver shows mild mixed portal inflammation with patchy mild macrovesicular steatosis. No dPAS positive alpha-1-antitrypsin globules are seen. Special stains for iron and copper are pending. Thereis patchy early fibrosis. No convincing cirrhosis is seen. 
Immunohistochemical stains were performed and the results are as follows:
Lesion positive for: SMA (strong background staining within area of confluent fibrosis).
Lesion negative for: Desmin, CAM5.2, CD23, CD21, ALK1 and pancytokeratin (non-specific).  
Kappa and lambda stains show no evidenceof light chain restriction.
B.  Sections of gallbladder show chronic active cholecystitis. The lamina propria contains a moderate, diffuse mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate, including numerous neutrophils. In areas, the neutrophils infiltrate the surface epithelium and there are scattered lymphoid aggregates and follicles. The muscularis propria is thickened and there is Rokitansky-Aschoff sinus formation. One pericholecystic lymph node shows reactive change (0/1). There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy. 
COMMENT:
The left lateral liver lesion consists of a broad area of confluent fibrosis containing variably ectatic to narrowed bile ducts and a moderate to heavy mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate. There is prominent diffuse staining for SMA, and desmin, ALK-1 and cytokeratin stains are negative. The overall histologic features favour hepatolithiasis with an obstructive cholangitis, large duct obstruction within the adjacent liver and a chronic active cholecystitis. However, the differential diagnosis could also include an inflammatory pseudo-tumour; primary inflammatory bile duct disease; and although considered less likely, an infective etiology. Given the broad differential diagnosis, this case will be sent to Professor RANDOLPH HYSMITH at DAYSURGERY UNIT Pathologists, for his expert opinion, and an additional report will be issued. 
DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Left lateral liver: Hepatolithiasis with an associated fibroinflammatory lesion, bile duct proliferation and features of large duct obstruction within the adjacent liver (see comment).

B.  Gallbladder: Chronic activecholecystitis.

This case is being sent to Professor Uhrig (Douglas Hanly Moir Pathologists) and a supplementary report will be issued.


SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT:  (26.8.63)
Professor Fregeau (SA Pathology Pathologists) reports:
"Microscopic:
There is a fibroinflammatory process with a ductocentric distribution.  The mixed inflammatory infiltrate includes plasma cells, eosinophils and neutrophils, as well as foreign body giant cells containing cholesterol crystals (see photograph 1) from calculous debris.There is a similar reaction on the inner surface of ulcerated larger ducts (see photograph 2). Periductal onion skinning fibrosis and oedema are also seen.  IgG4 staining is negative in the plasma cells (stain performed at STGEORGE PRIVATE).
Important:  I also considered the differential diagnoses you suggested, as well as IgG4 related disease.  The prominence of extraductal cholesterol debris and also focal duct dilation with residual calculous material leads me to favour your diagnosis of hepatolithiasis causing a fibroinflammatory "pseudotumour".  Localised or segmental PSC is considered less likely. 
A family history should betaken.  Some patients with hepatolithiasis develop stones because of low levels of MDR3 (ABCB4 mutation). A family history of the following: early cholecystitis (low phospholipid-associated cholecystitis - LPAC - syndrome),jaundice of pregnancy in females, drug induced jaundice and unexplained biliary cirrhosis can be present in patients with inherited MDR3 deficiency.  If the family history is suggestive, ursodeoxycholic acid is of benefit to prevent lithiasis. I am not aware of any Australian centres that provided MDR3 gene analysis".

HISTOPATHOLOGY REPORT:

*SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT ATTACHED*

HISTORY:
Ca ovry.  Omentum.

MACROSCOPIC:
&quot;OMENTUM&quot;. Consists of multiple pieces of unorientated fibroadipose tissue and blood clot, 6-200mm in size and 200x210x50mm in aggregate.  On the fatty tissue, resembling omentum, there are milky white, thick areas, which are present on both the surface and within the fatty tissue.

(1-3 RS from the largest piece of fatty tissue; 4 sections from the second largest piece of tissue; 5 RS of a smaller piece of lobulated fatty tissue; 6 sections from a more fibromembraneous area). RS (M-6/LK/ank)

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr. L Sperow)
Sections show adipose tissue extensively infiltrated by a clear cell tumour.  The tumour has a predominantly papillary growth pattern, but also shows areas of tubular growth pattern.  There are scattered psammoma bodies present.  The papillary cores in some areas have a hyalinised appearance.  In some areas, eosinophilic material is seen within the tubular structures.  Individual tumour cells have abundant clear cytoplasm, and irregular nuclei with some nuclear membrane folding, and small nucleoli.  There is little or no nuclear stratification in most areas.  Mitotic figures are extremely sparse (less than 1 per 10 high power fields).  Immunohistochemical stains show that the tumour is positive for EMA, PAX8, Ber-EP4, CK7, and HBME-1.  It shows very weak variable focal positivity for p53, and very focal positivity for Napsin A.  It is negative for WT1, cytokeratin 20, calretinin, CEA, p16, AMACR, and D-240.
This case has been subject to intradepartmental consultation.  The appearances raise a differential diagnosis of clear cell carcinoma versus serous carcinoma.  The overall histologic appearance and immunohistochemical staining pattern favours clear cell carcinoma.  While the female genital tract is the most likely site of origin, clinical correlation is required as to likely primary site.
DIAGNOSIS:
OMENTUM:
- FAVOUR CLEAR CELL CARCINOMA.
- CLINICAL CORRELATION IS REQUIRED AS TO MOST LIKELY SITE OF ORIGIN (PLEASE SEE TEXT AND COMMENT ABOVE).

CLINICAL:
64F laparotomy + BSO +/- omentectomy/omental biopsy for complex pelvic mass with large ascites.


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left fallopian tube and ovary&quot;, consists of a solid adnexal mass, 190 x 160 x 110mm, with attached oedematous fallopian tube, 45 x 6mm. The solid mass appears separate to a nodule of presumed ovary, 45 x 25 x 15mm. The mass has a smooth and shiny serosal surface with underlying petechial haemorrhages and possible necrotic change. On section, the cut surface shows a diffuse fibrous appearance with intervening small areas of bright yellow discolouration. An area of haemorrhagic change is present, 40 x 30 x 25mm,  underlying the serosal fibrinous exudate. This region comprises less than ten percent of the whole tumour volume. Patchy cystic and mucoid change is seen throughout. Blocks: 1 and 2 - RS fallopian tube; 3 - haemorrhagic area; 4 and 5- cystic myxoid areas; 6 to 14 - RS through fibrous area; 15 - mass with adjacent ?ovarian parenchyma.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right fallopian tube and ovary&quot;, consists of a fallopian tube, ovary and attached adnexal fibroadipose tissue, 55 x 50 x 28mm in total. The length of the fallopian tube is difficult to appreciate within adnexal tissue. The ovary is 34 x 25 x 25mm. On section, the ovary has a uniform densely fibrotic appearance. Blocks: 1 and 2 - RS fallopian tube; 3 to 5 - RS through ovary (fifty percent embedded).

C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Pouch of Douglas&quot;, consists of pale and haemorrhagic tissue fragments, 25 x 15 x 5mm in aggregate. AE 1 block.

D.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omental biopsy&quot;, consists of a piece of omental type fat, 140 x 35 x 10mm. No peritoneal nodules or infiltrative masses are identified. RS 3 blocks. (TO:AP/vo 2/5/07)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr S Towlson):
A. The sections show a large fibroma with areas of oedema, haemorrhage, necrosis and associated mixed inflammatory cells. The tumour is comprised of bundles of spindle cells in a fibrotic and variably oedematous background, with no significant nuclear atypia or hypercellularity and scant mitoses (up to 1 / 10hpf).  A few scattered chronic inflammatory cells are seen in the lesion.  There is fibrinoid change around some of the blood vessels, with atherosis also seen in a few vessels.  A thin layer of fibrinous exudate is present on the serosal surface.
The ovary is separate from the mass lesion. The ovary shows corpora albicantes.
Mild active chronic inflammation and oedema are noted in the fallopian tube.
No evidence of malignancy or dysplasia is seen.
Haemorrhage, necrosis, oedema and associated inflammatory cells are likely due to torsion injury of a large fibroma rather tumour necrosis.  Correlation with clinical features is recommended.

B. The sections of the ovary show corpora albicantes, surface inclusion cysts and areas of stromal hyperplasia. There is no evidence of malignancy or atypia.

C.  The sections show sheets of cells with areas of necrosis and some associated inflammatory cells with some fatty tissue.  The cells have monotonous, round nuclei without prominent nucleoli and moderate amounts of eosinophilic, slightly vacuolated cytoplasm.   Immunohistochemistry shows widespread expression of pan keratin (Cam 5.2) antigens. There are also many cells expressing CD68 antigen, a histiocytic marker. Calretinin antigen is expressed in a more patchy distribution compared to pan keratin antigens, probably because many of the cells are degenerate.  Inhibin antigen is not expressed. There is no convincing expression of oestrogen and progesterone receptor antigens. Ki67 is expressed in an estimated 3% of cells.
These features are consistent with nodular mesothelial hyperplasia with no evidence of malignancy.

D. The sections show lobulated mature adipose tissue consistent with omentum. Patchy mild to moderate chronic inflammation, fibrosis and mesothelial hyperplasia are seen.  There is no evidence of malignancy or atypia.

DIAGNOSIS:
A. Left ovary and fallopian tube: Fibroma with changes consistent with torsion injury.
B. Right ovary and fallopian tube: Surface inclusion cysts, patchy stromal hyperplasia.
C. Pouch of Douglas: Consistent with nodular mesothelial hyperplasia
D. Omental biopsy: Mild to moderate chronic inflammation.

Pathology ReportCLINICAL:
Retroperitoneal tumour (?sarcoma). Para-aortic mass. Core needle biopsy (DHM) reported high grade sarcomatoid  tumour. Previous history of a testicular germ cell tumour approximately 13yrs ago and had retroperitoneal lymph node dissection. Para-aortic tumour en block resection with infra-renal aorta.

Confirmed with Dr SHAWN DEANGELES (surgical oncology fellow) that main specimen does not require formal orientation as tumour macroscopically extend to margins (AP 16/3/71).


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Para-cable mass (?sarcoma)&quot;, consists of a 25 x 15 x 10mm nodule with a cream and vaguely nodular cut surface. Bisected and half embedded for frozen section.  Blocks: 1 - frozen section; 2 - remaining tissue. AE.
B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Peri-aortic tumour&quot;, consists of a segment of aorta 43mm long to a diameter of 17mm (lumen 10mm) with surrounding adherent soft tissue, 50 x 42 x 35mm. Tissue is sampled fresh for biobanking. No anatomical landmarks are present for definite orientation (confirmed with surgical team orientation not required). The tissue is arbitrarily inked blue and black. The cut surface shows heterogeneous soft tissue surrounding a fibrotic aortic wall with focal fatty streaks. Whilst heterogeneous soft tissue may represent tumour, no measurable discrete lesion is identified. Numerous lymph nodes measuring up to 7mm in greatest dimension are distributed throughout the soft tissue. No tumour thrombus or luminal thrombus formation is seen. Blocks: 1 - TS one end (partial aorta); 2 - full face of tumour (big block); 3 to 5 - composite section; 6 to 8 - composite section; 9 &amp; 10 - composite section; 11 - TS shave other end aorta. Macroscopic photo available.
C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left retro-caval&quot;, consists of a nodular piece of tan and white tissue, 13 x 6 x 5mm.   AE 1 block.
D.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right superior renal mass&quot;, consists of an irregular piece of fibrofatty tissue, 35 x 28 x 13mm. The cut surface has a heterogeneous fibrofatty appearance. Blocks: 1 - TS ends; 2 &amp; 3 - TS through middle. AE.
E.  Specimen labelled &quot;Anterior aortic tissue at renal vessels&quot;, consists of a strip of fibrous tissue, 15 x 5 x 2mm.   AE 1 block.   (TO:AP/ta 16/3/71)
FROZEN SECTION REPORT:
A. Fibrosis bland cartilage and epithelium. If previous testicular tumour is a germ cell tumour may represent treatment effect with mature teratoma. Discussed with the surgical reg. Previous orchidectomy performed in New Zealand 15yrs ago.
Result phoned to Surgical registrar by Dr J Stencel and Dr J Sacks at 12:15 on 12/1/21.


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr J Ernspiker):
A. Paraffin embedded sections show fibrocollagenous tissue with patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis containing scattered islands of mature cartilage. A simple mucin lined ductule is also seen. In the clinical context of previous testicular tumour this is favoured to represent a focus of residual mature teratoma with treatment effect/fibrosis. There is no evidence of malignant germ cell tumour or sarcoma.

B. Sections show aorta with surrounding peri-aortic tissue. There is extensive involvement of the fibrotic periaortic soft tissue by an infiltrative malignant sarcomatoid tumour. In the blocks submitted, the overall estimated maximum tumour dimension is 22mm (however, tumour is present at the margin and total tumour extent cannot be determined). The tumour is composed of malignant spindled to epithelioid cells arranged in dense cellular infiltrative sheets which dissect through periaortic fibrocollagen. In areas, the tumour cells appear to form malignant, anastomosing vascular channels lined by malignant hobnailed endothelial cells. The vasoformative tumour abuts and infiltrates into the adventitia and outer media of the aorta. Mitoses are readily identified and there are scattered foci of tumour necrosis. The tumour shows extensive crush type artefact and multifocal perineural involvement. The tumour extends broadly to the edges of the excision.

Five lymph nodes are identified, one of which shows direct infiltration by tumour (1/5).

Immunohistochemistry demonstrates positivity for vascular markers ERG, CD31 and CD34, as well as, BCL-2 (patchy), synaptophysin (weak),  Additional stains for inhibin, myogenin, LCA, WT1 (cytoplasm staining only), PLAP, AFP, desmin, tdt, pancytokeratin, CD56, SMA, TLE-1, MIC-2, CAM5.2, SOX-10 and OCT-34 are negative. INI-1 shows preserved (normal) nuclear staining.

In addition, within the surrounding fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue, there are occasional foci of cartilage on a background of broad nodules and sheets of dense organised fibrosis with  superimposed dystrophic calcification, fat necrosis and inflammation. Several entrapped medium to large nerves and ganglia are also seen. These background changes are suggestive of focal residual mature teratoma on a background of previous treatment related effect.

C. Section show fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue showing fibrosis with superimposed patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis. No cartilage is seen. There is no evidence of malignancy.

D. Sections show fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue showing fibrosis with superimposed patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis. A 1.1mm focus of adrenal cortical parenchyma, as well as, seven reactive appearing lymph nodes (0/7). No cartilage is seen. There is no evidence of malignancy.

E. Section show fibrocollagenous and adipose tissue showing fibrosis with superimposed patchy chronic inflammation and fat necrosis. A single reactive lymph node is seen. No cartilage is identified. There is no evidence of malignancy.


COMMENT:
The presence of islands of residual mature cartilage associated with organising fibrosis, inflammation, dystrophic calcification and fat necrosis in specimens A and B (para caval and peri aortic masses), is highly suggestive of residual mature teratoma on a background of treatment associated change. No evidence of malignant germ cell elements are seen.

As reported in the previous biopsy by Professor Jaussen, there is an associated peri-aortic high grade malignant sarcoma, which may represent: (a) malignant transformation arising within the previously treated para-aortic tumour; (b) or, a de novo sarcoma. In these specimens, the high grade sarcoma demonstrates malignant vasoformative morphology, as well as, strong diffuse staining with endothelial markers, consistent with a high grade angiosarcoma.
Sarcoma is present at margins.


DIAGNOSIS:
A. Para-caval mass: Favour residual mature teratoma with treatment effects. No evidence of malignant germ cell tumour, sarcoma or malignancy.

B. Peri-aortic tumour:
- Malignant vasoformative tumour, consistent with high grade angiosarcoma, present at margins.
- One of five lymph nodes shows direct invasion by angiosarcoma.
- Background nodular organised fibrosis and dystrophic calcification ?treatment related change.

C. Left retrocaval: Fibrosis and patchy mild non-specific chronic inflammation.

D. Right superior renal mass: 1.1mm focus of adrenal cortex on a background of multiple ganglia, fibrosis and inflammation. Seven reactive lymph nodes are present.

E. Anterior aortic tissue at renal vessels: Fibrosis and patchy mild non-specific chronic inflammation (0/1).

MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr K Hartfiel):
A.  Sections show a serous carcinoma involving serosa and parametrium of uterus, both ovaries and fallopian tubes.  The tumourshows predominately psammomatous calcification (more than 95%).  Focally, neoplastic serous epithelium is present (less than 5%) with mild cytological atypia and papillary architecture.  Tumour cells with high grade nuclei are also focally seen.  Within the tumour, there is extensive fibrosis and numerous foamy macrophages.  In the right clinical setting the appearances are in keeping with those of previous neoadjuvant therapy.  The uterus shows a large intramural leiomyoma.  There is a large endometrial polyp with cystically dilated gland.  The rest of endometrium is atrophic.  The cervix is unremarkable.  For both ovaries, the tumour mainly involves the surface and outer halves of cortex.  The lumen of right fallopian tube is completely filled by tumour.  In the specimen A, the tumour appears to be centred on right fallopian tube and right ovary.
B.  Sections show fibrofatty tissue involved by a serous carcinoma with extensive psammomatous calcification (more than 95%).  The appearances are identical those described in the specimen A.
C.  Sections show a serous carcinoma with extensive psammomatous calcification (more than 95%).  The appearancesare identical those described in the specimen A.
D.  Sections show omental tissue involved by a serous carcinoma with extensive psammomatous calcification (more than 95%).  The appearances are identical those described in the specimen A.
Comment:
The tumour shows extensive psammomatous calcification (more than 95%).  It is difficult to properly grade the tumour due to minimal amount of neoplastic epithelium (less than 5%).  The presence of extensive fibrosis and numerous macrophages is suggestive of previous neoadjuvant therapy.  If the patient had received neoadjuvant therapy, please refer to previous biopsy for tumour grading.  The most likely primary site is peritoneum.  The right fallopian tube is another possibility.  Clinical correlation is needed.  The case is shown to Dr K Byker and Dr BRYAN HALLIMAN.

The ovary is sectioned transversely into 9 slices and shows a relatively well circumscribed 19 x 11 x approximately 20mm pale yellow lesion underlying the puckered serosal region (slices 4 to 8).  The fallopian tube is sectioned transversely into 11 slices and the fimbrial end bisected longitudinally.
Blocks:  F1 to F4 - right fallopian tube serially embedded from isthmus to fimbria; F5 - ovary, slice three with cyst; F6 &amp; F7 - ovary with yellow lesion and serosal puckering (F7 also with separate serosal nodule), slices 5 and 6. F8-F11 additional blocks ovary.

G.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of 265 x 60 x 10mm of omental fat. Numerous (&gt;15) firm nodules, 2 to 7mm in extent, are scattered throughout the omentum.  Some have a spiculated pale cream cut surface (?fibrosis or tumour).
Blocks:  G1 - two nodules; G2 - five nodules; G3 - one nodule, bisected; G4 - three nodules; G5 - three nodules; G6 &amp; G7 - one nodule bisected per block.

H.  Specimen labelled &quot;Peritoneal nodule&quot;, consists of four irregular fibrofatty tissues, 7 to 20mm in extent and 25 x 15 x 7mm in aggregate.  The two largest pieces are surfaced by presumed pale grey serosa. The largest is trisected and shows an 8 x 2mm firm cream to yellow region extending from the peritoneal surface.  The second piece of presumed serosa also shows an 8 x 2mm thickened area (bisected).
Blocks:  H1 - larger piece bisected; H2 - smaller three pieces (one bisected). AE.

I.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right sidewall&quot;, consists of an 11 x 7 x 3mm irregular grey tissue. Bisected, AE 1 block.

J. Specimen labelled &quot;Nodule bladder peritoneum&quot;, consists of an 8 x 6 x 4mm fibrofatty tissue, surfaced on one side by a possible pale grey serosa.  Bisected, AE 1 block.  (TO: KM; KM/eh 22/4/2067)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr Z Erschen):
A.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show core biopsies of pancreatic tissue.  There is marked acinar atrophy with replacement dense hyaline type fibrosis. There is background retention of a lobular architecture however interspersed amongst the dense fibrous tissue are occasional atypical tubular glands. The glands show  mild to focally moderate nuclear pleomorphism which is difficult to assess in a frozen section sample.  Features often associated with carcinoma in core biopsy samples such as nuclear size variation of 3:1, conspicuous macronucleoli, disrupted glands, perineural invasion, necrosis in lumina are not definitively present, however the glands are atypical and the context of the appearances seen in specimen B likely represent well differentiated adenocarcinoma.

B.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show a wedge of pancreatic tissue which is partially infiltrated by a well differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows an infiltrative pattern amongst background pancreatic parenchyma which shows variable acinar atrophy.  The glands are tubular with focal secondary lumina and are lined by cells with minimal or mild nuclear pleomorphism and a small to moderate amount eosinophilic cytoplasm.  No morphological evidence of intestinal differentiation such as goblet cells or Paneth cells are seen.  There is associated fibromyxoid desmoplastic stroma and foci of perineural and intraneural invasion are also seen.  No associated extracellular mucin is present.  The sample includes uninvolved pancreatic parenchyma and the ducts here do not show evidence of high grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN).  No lymph nodes are identified.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is seen.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

C.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show oedematous fibrovascular cores surfaced by variably ciliated Mullerian type epithelium showing hierarchical branching.  Although some of the papillae appear unsupported they are not four times as high as they are wide.  Nuclear atypia is mild to moderate.  No features of microinvasion are seen. The features are those of a low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Sections of ovary show invasive adenocarcinoma.  Differentiation varies with predominantly well to moderate differentiation and a minor poorly differentiated component.  The tumour is composed of tubular and cribriform glandular structures within a moderately cellular oedematous desmoplastic stroma.  In addition to small tubular and cribriform structures the tumour also contains a component of more cystically dilated glands a proportion of which are lined by very bland or mildly atypical simple or stratified columnar mucinous epithelium. Expansile nodular or intracystic papillary growth is not seen.  Some of the cystically dilated areas show higher grade nuclear atypia. Whilst the tumour mainly shows destructive stromal invasion with associated desmoplasia, some area including the cysts are associated with ovarian stroma in a pattern resembling an ovarian mucinous borderline neoplasm  with and without intracystic carcinoma .  The poorly differentiated component comprises minor foci (less than 5%) in which there is either single cell infiltration or signet ring-like differentiation (eg D8, D16, D18).  No associated extracellular mucin deposition to indicate pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  No microscopic surface mucin, or surface deposits are seen. Two small areas of surface disruption are noted.    Occasional glands contain necrotic luminal debris which are predominantly of inflammatory cells with some associated necrotic epithelial cells. Invasive adenocarcinoma involves the fallopian tube with invasion of the wall from the serosal surface (D18, D20) reaching the mucosa at the fimbrial end (D21) .  There is focal endometriosis close to the fallopian tube (D21). The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and no serous tubular carcinoma in-situ is seen.  No benign Brenner component is seen. The ovarian hilum is not identified.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.


E.  Sections of uterus show metastatic adenocarcinoma seenpredominantly surface deposits on the anterior surface (E4).  Adenocarcinoma is also present in the vicinity of the right cornua (E10) and close to the posterior peritoneal reflection (E12).  The carcinoma shows similar morphology to the pancreatic and ovarian disease.   There are also foci of endosalpingiosis (eg E5, E7) as well as endometriosis (E13).  The uterus shows a couple of fibroids (E14, E1) and is otherwise unremarkable. The endometrium is predominantly basal but appears inactive.  The ectocervix and and endocervix are uninvolved and unremarkable.

F.  The right ovary is extensively sampled and the attached fallopian tube including fimbrial end entirely embedded and examined.  Sections of ovary confirm a surface serous low grade borderline tumour associated with psammomatous calcifications as well as multiple deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows similar features to that seen in the left ovary and pancreas.  The deposits are seen on the surface of the ovary and also as a single expansile nodule. The expansile nodule shows areas in which the malignant glands are present with  ovarian stroma as well as areas with stromal  desmoplasia. The surface deposits which show similar cytomorphology are present amongst desmoplastic stroma.  The glands show a tubular and cribriform morphology with some poorly differentiated areas with single cell growth (eg F6).  No pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  Metastatic moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma is also seen within the right ovarian hilum (F11).  Definite lymphovascular invasion is not identified.  Foci of endometriosis are also seen (F11).The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and is unremarkable and uninvolved.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the adenocarcinoma stains as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

In contrast to the adenocarcinoma the serous borderline tumour shows typical expression for PAX8, WT1, CK7, ER and PR. CK19 is also positive while CK20 and CDX2 are negative.

G.  Sections of omentum show multiple foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar morphology to that seen within the ovaries and pancreas. The carcinoma is composed of small tubular and cribriform glands within a desmoplastic stroma and is seen on the serosal surface associated with mesothelial cell reaction.  Scattered foci of psammomatous calcification are seen both in the vicinity of tumour and separately.  Foci of endosalpingiosis are also seen (G5 and G6). One lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

H.   Sections of peritoneal lined adipose tissue show several deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows similar morphology to that seen within the pancreas and ovaries. The carcinoma is composed of surface deposits within desmoplastic stroma. The carcinoma appears well to moderately differentiated with well formed tubular or cribriform glands.  One small lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

I &amp; J.  Sections of fibroadipose tissue show a deposit of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar features to that seen in the other sites.  The carcinoma is well to moderately differentiated.


COMMENT:
The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr Z Montecillo who favours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Stephen comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.


DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Pancreatic core biopsy (frozen section):
-    Atypical mucinous epithelium which in this context is consistent with adenocarcinoma.

B.  Pancreatic biopsy (frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma with perineural invasion (see comment).

C.  Right ovarian lesion (frozen section):
-    Low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Left ovary and fallopian tube (including frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma within ovary and fallopian tube (see comment).

E.  Uterus:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis and endometriosis.
-    Fibroids.

F.  Right ovary and fallopian tube:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma in ovary.
-    Ovarian low grade serous borderline tumour.
-    Uninvolved fallopian tube

G.  Omentum:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.
-    Endosalpingiosis.

H.  Peritoneal nodule:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

I.   Right side wall:
-    Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

J.   Nodule peritoneum:
-     Metastatic adenocarcinoma.

The findings were discussed with Drs Z Javellana &amp; Z Stauder and  Profs. Z Kunzie and Z Holtberg.
